content.raw:
This is not ready for a merge, but I just want feedback if I am going in the right direction or not. \(I am not sure how else I can show you a diff between my branch and master, if there is a more appropriate way than making a PR, please tell me\)

* Firstly, am I going towards the right direction? \(creating a note and an `onCollisionMsg` function\)
* What should happen when a collision is detected? I am thinking I should just make a counter of how many times the wamv is hit so that may be used later for score calculation.
* Brian mentions in the issue “Plugin should include logic so that only one event is recorded per incident”. Right now I implement that using the timer. Is there a preferable way of doing this?
content.html:
This is not ready for a merge, but I just want feedback if I am going in the right direction or not. (I am not sure how else I can show you a diff between my branch and master, if there is a more appropriate way than making a PR, please tell me)

  • Firstly, am I going towards the right direction? (creating a note and an onCollisionMsg function)
  • What should happen when a collision is detected? I am thinking I should just make a counter of how many times the wamv is hit so that may be used later for score calculation.
  • Brian mentions in the issue “Plugin should include logic so that only one event is recorded per incident”. Right now I implement that using the timer. Is there a preferable way of doing this?

@ykhky , this is looking very good.

One potential idea for your question about what to do is to accept a parameter with the score to be added when we hit an obstacle (e.g.: the parameter could be -1). Another idea could be to register a callback function to be executed when there’s a collision. I’d go for the simpler approach unless we really need to do something more custom.

I think your solution using a timer is good for the problem of recording multiple events of the same incident.

content.html: @Youssef Khaky, are you still actively working on this issue?

content.raw:
For my testing I added a message output here to report a counted collision, e.g.,

```
    gzmsg << "[" << this.collisionCounter <<
                "] New collision counted between [" <<
                contacts->contact(i).collision1() <<
                "] and [" << contacts->contact(i).collision2() << "]" << std::endl;
    
    gzdbg << contacts->contact(i).DebugString() << std::endl;
```
content.html:
For my testing I added a message output here to report a counted collision, e.g.,

    gzmsg << "[" << this.collisionCounter <<
                "] New collision counted between [" <<
                contacts->contact(i).collision1() <<
                "] and [" << contacts->contact(i).collision2() << "]" << std::endl;

    gzdbg << contacts->contact(i).DebugString() << std::endl;

content.raw: I think this is a useful print, I will add it to the PR.
content.html: I think this is a useful print, I will add it to the PR.

content.raw:
I did some ad-hoc testing driving round the navigation task example and running into things \(roslaunch vrx\_gazebo navigation\_task.launch verbose:=true\).  It seems to work well and is a great start on being able to keep track of collisions for the purposes of the contest.  

A couple of additional features that we might consider useful - could be future enhancements if not part of this PR.

* Keeping track of collisions.  Beyond counting the system should keep a record of the collisions.  Perhaps and array containing the list of collisions where each collision is a time-stamp and the name of the other object involved in the collision.  
* Reporting collisions via ROS API to relay some of the information from the Gazebo contacts information.  Would think that the message would contain names of the two collision objects and a timestamp.

Thoughts?
content.html:
I did some ad-hoc testing driving round the navigation task example and running into things (roslaunch vrx_gazebo navigation_task.launch verbose:=true). It seems to work well and is a great start on being able to keep track of collisions for the purposes of the contest.

A couple of additional features that we might consider useful - could be future enhancements if not part of this PR.

  • Keeping track of collisions. Beyond counting the system should keep a record of the collisions. Perhaps and array containing the list of collisions where each collision is a time-stamp and the name of the other object involved in the collision.
  • Reporting collisions via ROS API to relay some of the information from the Gazebo contacts information. Would think that the message would contain names of the two collision objects and a timestamp.

Thoughts?

content.raw:
* I think this is a  useful enhancement. The collision log can help in understanding the score outcome.
* ROS API:

    * Pro: collisions would appear in the bag file which can be helpful in debugging. \(eg: noticing relationship between collision and sensor reliability.
    * Concern:  It can be used as a “sensor” while the real wamv does not have a collision sensor attached to it.
content.html:
• I think this is a useful enhancement. The collision log can help in understanding the score outcome.

  • ROS API:

    • Pro: collisions would appear in the bag file which can be helpful in debugging. (eg: noticing relationship between collision and sensor reliability.
    • Concern: It can be used as a “sensor” while the real wamv does not have a collision sensor attached to it.

content.raw: We have run into this with some of the other plugins for the competition.  One solution is to have an flag in the configuration to control if the collision information is ROS published.  This allows teams to use the information for debugging/development, but then it can be turned off during the actual competition.
content.html: We have run into this with some of the other plugins for the competition. One solution is to have an flag in the configuration to control if the collision information is ROS published. This allows teams to use the information for debugging/development, but then it can be turned off during the actual competition.

content.raw: I have implemented keeping track of collisions. In two new variables `collisionList` and `collisionTimestamps`
content.html: I have implemented keeping track of collisions. In two new variables collisionList and collisionTimestamps

content.raw: Should we make this function private? Also, for consistency, could you rename it to `OnCollisionMsg()`? Could you also document the parameter and rename it to `_contacts`?
content.html: Should we make this function private? Also, for consistency, could you rename it to OnCollisionMsg()? Could you also document the parameter and rename it to _contacts?

content.raw: I think these two member variables can be private. Feel free to move them down to the private member declaration section.
content.html: I think these two member variables can be private. Feel free to move them down to the private member declaration section.

content.raw: I'd suggest to make these members `protected`. This way, other specific scoring plugins can have access to them. Maybe `CollisionBuffer` is the only one that could stay private \(could you also rename it to `collisionBuffer`?\)
content.html: I'd suggest to make these members protected. This way, other specific scoring plugins can have access to them. Maybe CollisionBuffer is the only one that could stay private (could you also rename it to collisionBuffer?)

content.raw: I will  change `lastCollisionTime` to protected as that may be useful for other plugins, I don’t think  `collisionBuffer` would be needed by other plugins.
content.html: I will change lastCollisionTime to protected as that may be useful for other plugins, I don’t think collisionBuffer would be needed by other plugins.

content.raw:
I made a few minor comments in the code. My major suggestion would be to create a virtual `OnCollision()` function, similar to `OnReady()`, `OnRunning()` and `OnFinished()` and we call it every time that we consider a collision. We can offer an empty implementation in `scoring_plugin.cc` . This way, other derived plugins can optionally override the `OnCollision()` function, and detect the exact time where the collision happens \(and change score or react accordingly\).

Ready to approve after these suggestions.
content.html:
I made a few minor comments in the code. My major suggestion would be to create a virtual OnCollision() function, similar to OnReady(), OnRunning() and OnFinished() and we call it every time that we consider a collision. We can offer an empty implementation in scoring_plugin.cc . This way, other derived plugins can optionally override the OnCollision() function, and detect the exact time where the collision happens (and change score or react accordingly).

Ready to approve after these suggestions.
